what.title: What is clr.fund?
what.paragraph: Clr.fund, pronounced "Clear Fund", is a protocol for efficiently allocating funds to public goods that benefit the Ethereum Network according to the preferences of the Ethereum Community. Clr.fund strives for credible neutrality, decentralization, permissionlessness, trustlessness, and pseudonymity.

why.title: Why does clr.fund exist?
why.paragraph-1-text-2: ‚Äî commodities or services that are neither excludable nor subtractable ‚Äî is a challenge for any ecosystem, and Ethereum is no exception.
why.paragraph-2: Clr.fund‚Äôs goal is to enable funds to be allocated towards public goods that benefit the Ethereum Network without relying on centralized entities and in a way that reflects the preferences of the Ethereum Community.
why.paragraph-3-text-2: for more detail on clr.fund‚Äôs goals and values.

unique.title: How is clr.fund unique?
unique.paragraph-1: Clr.fund instances also have a number of other special properties:
unique.li-1-text-1: Decentralization ‚Äî Major pieces of clr.fund's infrastructure are built on
unique.li-1-text-2: , A programmable blockchain that provides a reliable, censorship-resistant ledger for clr.fund's voting and funding transactions.
unique.li-2-text-1: Scalability ‚Äî Because using Ethereum can be expensive for users, clr.fund uses
unique.li-2-text-2: supplementary networks to get most of the benefits of the main Ethereum network but with faster, cheaper transactions.
unique.li-2-link-1: Learn more about clr.fund's use of layer 2.
unique.li-3-text-1: Collusion-resistance ‚Äî Since blockchains like Ethereum publish all data publicly by default, clr.fund contributors are vulnerable to bribery and other kinds of manipulation. Clr.fund helps prevent these attacks using magical math called zero-knowledge proofs.
unique.li-3-link-1: Find out about MACI, our Minimal Anti-Collusion Infrastructure.
unique.li-4-text-1: Sybil-resistance ‚Äî Voting systems that care about the number of individual people voting for a given choice, as quadratic funding does, can be vulnerable to sybil attacks, in which one person sets up many identities in order to vote multiple times. Clr.fund mitigates this threat with an identity-system called BrightID.
unique.paragraph-2: Clr.fund is also built so anyone can spin up and run their own instance to create a public goods grant program for their particular public.

how.title: How does it work?
how.paragraph-1-text-1: The clr.fund protocol uses the Constrained Liberal Radicalism (CLR) algorithm, commonly called
how.paragraph-1-text-2: (QF), to facilitate monetary contributions from members of the Ethereum Community towards builders of Ethereum public goods.
how.paragraph-2: With its logic encoded into Ethereum smart contracts and other web3 technologies, clr.fund requires minimal trust in any individual people or entities to function and is resilient to collusion and bribery.
how.paragraph-3: At a high-level, clr.fund consists of a matching pool and a funding round. Philanthropic individuals or organizations contribute to the matching pool so as to have those funds efficiently allocated according to community preference. Users contribute directly to projects they value and, in doing so, earn a share of the matching pool for the projects, along with their contribution. Effectively increasing the value of their contribution.
how.paragraph-4-text-1: Under the hood, clr.fund uses zero-knowledge proofs (ZK-SNARKS), courtesy of the
how.paragraph-4-text-2: , to keep individual contributions private and limit effectiveness of collusion and bribery
how.paragraph-5: To ensure that every contributor is a unique person clr.fund uses.

heading.title: Contributor guide
heading.paragraph: An overview of how things work as a contributor so you can learn what to expect throughout the duration of a funding round.

funds.title: Get funds on {chain}
funds.paragraph-1-text-1: You'll need some {currency} on {chain} in order to submit transactions to the clr.fund smart contracts.

contributing.title: Contributing to specific projects
contributing.li-1-text-1: Before contributing to specific projects, you will need to
contributing.li-1-link-1: verify that you're a unique human
contributing.li-2: Make sure you have {nativeTokenSymbol} in your BrightID-verified wallet on the {chain} network
contributing.li-3-text: and add some to your cart, adjusting your contributions to the amount of {nativeTokenSymbol} you want.
contributing.li-4: When you're ready, open your cart, click contribute, and confirm the transactions to complete your contributions!
contributing.paragraph: Note: you can only contribute once. After submitting your contributions, you can reallocate them as much as you would like before of the reallocation phase but you cannot add more funds to your total contribution amount.
contributing.li-5: You can add and remove projects.
contributing.li-6: Your reallocation total must be less than or equal to the total (if it's less, the rest will go to the matching pool).

matching.title: Contributing to the matching pool
matching.paragraph-text-1: Not sure which specific to contribute to? Contributions to the matching pool will be distributed to all projects that receive project-specific contributions during that round. The weighting of this distribution is determined by the
matching.li-1: First make sure the wallet you are using holds {nativeTokenSymbol} on {chain}. {nativeTokenSymbol} can be easily purchased on any major Ethereum-focused exchange.
matching.li-2-text-1: Once you have the desired amount of {nativeTokenSymbol} in your wallet, select "Add Funds" on the

wow.title: How does clr.fund work
wow.paragraph: Looking for a more general overview?
wow.link: Check out our "How It Works" page

heading.title: Decentralization in Clr.fund
heading.subtitle: What is Decentralization?
heading.paragraph: When we say something is "decentralized" in clr.fund, and in web3 broadly, we mean that no single person, company, or other entity is solely responsible for running or maintaining it. Instead, a decentralized system is run or maintained by a large group of independent entities, coordinated by a set of rules each opts into, like miners in Ethereum or peers in BitTorrent.

which.title: Which pieces of clr.fund are decentralized?
which.paragraph-1: Much of clr.fund's infrastructure is built on Ethereum, a decentralized blockchain:
which.li-1: the registry of projects qualified for funding (and, potentially, the curation mechanism for choosing these projects)
which.li-3: the sybil-resistant registry of users qualified to contribute to individual projects
which.li-4: the funds from and encrypted information about contributions to individual projects
which.li-5: the mechanism for distributing funds once a round's results are finalized
which.exists_in_code: Each of these pieces exists in an Ethereum smart contract (see the code
which.maintained_by_miner: , meaning its functionality is maintained by Ethereum miners, a decentralized group.

why.title: Why is clr.fund decentralized?
why.paragraph: Ethereum's decentralization provides clr.fund with three main benefits:
why.li-1: Transparent process ‚Äî All of the decentralized pieces of clr.fund are publicly verifiable. Anyone can look at the code for the smart contracts and observe its inputs and outputs, with very little possibility that anything is being hidden or changed secretly.
why.li-2-text-1: Secure voting ‚Äî Because of Ethereum's strong security guarantees, anyone submitting a message can be extremely confident that their message will be processed as expected by the system. There are still security dangers, of course, such as
why.li-2-text-3: , but the kind of "vote hacking" typically feared in digital voting is highly unlikely here.
why.li-3-text-1: Public good ‚Äî Everything on Ethereum is open source and permissionless, which means the code for clr.fund's decentralized infrastructure acts as a public good: anyone can deploy their own version of the system to create their own
why.li-3-text-2: system, with the same decentralized benefits of the original.

heading.title: How the round works
heading.subtitle: CLR walkthrough
heading.paragraph-1: This is an overview of how everything works behind the scenes so you can learn what to expect throughout the duration of the round.
heading.paragraph-2: Looking for a guide on how to participate? Check out our guides specifically for contributing and joining as a project.

quick.title: Quick recap on quadratic funding
quick.paragraph-1-text-2: , projects will receive funding from individual contributions as well as the matching pool. When you contribute to your favorite projects, your contribution also acts as a vote. The more contributions a project receives, the more votes. And the more votes a project gets, the more they'll receive from the matching pool. Although a higher individual contribution will equal a larger vote weighting, it's far more important to receive a large volume of unique contributions than just a few high value contributions.
quick.paragraph-2: As the funding round is also a public vote, it needs deadlines. The round is split into multiple phases so that after all contributions or votes are made, they can be counted and confirmed before the final matching pool distribution.

phases.title: Funding round phases
phases.subtitle: Join phase
phases.paragraph-1-text-1: To kick things off, projects will be invited to
phases.paragraph-1-text-2: . If you're an eager contributor,   you'll be able to browse the projects and add them to your cart but you   won't be able to contribute just yet.

need.title: Need to know
need.li-1: There will be a maximum of {maxRecipients} projects in the round.
need.li-3-text: If you want to contribute, this is a perfect time to get

contribution.title: Contribution phase
contribution.paragraph-1: The launch of the contribution phase follows the join phase and marks the   official start of the funding round. This is the time for you to add your   favorite projects to your cart and contribute.

need.title: Need to know
need.li-2-text-1: You will need to go through some
need.li-4: Your total contribution amount is final. You can't increase it by contributing an additional time.

contribution.paragraph-2: If you don't contribute in the contribution phase, the round is over for   you once this phase ends.

reallocation.title: Reallocation phase
reallocation.paragraph: During this phase, if you've contributed, you will have time to change   your mind. You can edit your contribution amounts or add/remove projects   but your total must equal that of your original contribution.

need.title: Need to know
need.li-1: This phase will last {reallocationPhaseDays} days after the end of the contribution phase.
need.li-2: If you remove projects, you must reallocate the funds to other projects or it will go to the matching pool.
need.li-3: You can't exceed your original contribution total when reallocating funds.

tallying.title: Tallying phase
tallying.paragraph-text-1: At this point, all contributions are final, and can now be counted. The round coordinator triggers
tallying.paragraph-text-2: and the smart contracts to calculate how much of the matching pool each project will get.

finalized.title: Finalized phase
finalized.paragraph: Once the tallying calculations are complete, the round is finalized.   Project owners can come and claim their funding!

more.title: More
more.paragraph: We use different tech to keep the round fair and free from malicious   actors. You can learn more about them below:
more.li-1-text: ‚Äì to protect against bribery and tally round results.

heading.title: About Layer 2
heading.subtitle: Clr.fund on Layer 2
heading.paragraph-1-text-2: to help save you time and money when contributing to your favorite projects. You'll need a wallet with funds on {chain} to interact with this application.

transactions.title: Ethereum Transaction Costs
transactions.paragraph-1: Ethereum, the blockchain that houses much of clr.fund's infrastructure, requires users to pay transaction costs when interacting with it, and these costs are going up. Transaction fees compensate the decentralized community of Ethereum miners for processing and maintaining the blockchain's state securely. As usage of Ethereum has gone up, so has the price of getting miner's to include your transaction on the blockchain.
transactions.paragraph-2: So, the increasing cost of using Ethereum demonstrates that it's useful, which is great, but it also presents a problem for end users who don't want to pay fees in the 10s or 100s of dollars.

scalability.title: Layer 2s for Scalability
scalability.p1: The main Ethereum blockchain, "layer 1", may be upgraded to reduce costs in the future (this is one of the goals for the future of Ethereum, which clr.fund is helping realize!).
scalability.p2: In the immediate term, though, "layer 2" solutions are already helping dramatically reduce costs. Most layer 2s are "rollups", blockchain-esque systems that are maintained, like Ethereum, by a decentralized group of nodes. Rollups periodically "roll up" all their recent transactions into a single transaction that is recorded on layer 1, Ethereum, allowing them to inherit much of Ethereum's security.
scalability.p3: Transactions on layer 2s are orders of magnitude cheaper than on layer 1, since rollups can process a high rate of transactions and transaction traffic is now diluted across the many layer 2 options.

arbitrum.p1: There are many variations on the layer 2 rollup approach. This current {operator} round uses {chain}, an "optimistic"-style rollup.
arbitrum.subtitle: What you'll need
arbitrum.h3: üíº How to find wallet that supports {chain}
arbitrum.tooltip: Wallet resources are provided as a convenience and do not represent endorsement of any of the projects or services therein. Always DYOR.
arbitrum.li3_t2: and filter by "Wallets" to view some of the wallets that currently support the {chain} network.
arbitrum.li4_t1: Double-check that any wallet you consider
arbitrum.li4_t2: to ensure you're able to connect to the app.

funds.p1_t2: as a guide at any time.
funds.li1: Click above to go to the official {chain} bridge

funds.p2_t1: Once you have bridged your {nativeTokenSymbol} to {chain}, you may want to add the

what.p1: tl;dr: bribers are ngmi (not going to make it)
what.p2: Clr.fund uses MACI, Minimum Anti-Collusion Infrastructure, to help prevent vote manipulation like bribery or collusion. To understand why this is important let's recap quadratic funding...

quadratic.p1: This is the mechanism clr.fund uses in our funding rounds. When you contribute to a project you're not just sending them money, you're voting for them. At the end, the matching pool funds are distributed to projects based on number of votes at the end of the round.
quadratic.p3: This mechanism is great for democratic funding but poses some risks. It could be cost-effective for a project owner to bribe users to vote for their project as their eventual matching pool amount could be really high. This type of fraud puts the entire concept at risk as it is no longer about which projects offer the most value to the most amount of people.

background.p1: Vote manipulation involves maliciously changing the incentives of a voting system, and it comes in many flavors, including:
background.li1: Bribery ‚Äî when a person or entity offers to pay others to vote for an outcome they otherwise might not have, e.g. paying a football team to throw a match
background.li2: Coercion ‚Äî when a person or entity threatens to punish others in some way if they don't vote for a particular outcome, e.g. blackmail
background.p2: These kinds of manipulation break voting systems by diverting them from their intended goal. Voting systems are generally designed to discover a group's preference between a number of specified outcomes. Each voter is expected to choose how to vote based on which outcomes they prefer and how their vote can effect the result.
background.p3: In an election where the outcomes are 1) Alice wins and 2) Bob wins, if I prefer Alice winning and believe my vote has a high enough chance of influencing the result to be worth the effort, I'll vote for Alice. Now, let's say Charlie offers me $1,000,000 to vote for Bob instead. For me, the possible outcomes of the election now shift to 1) Alice wins and 2) Bob wins and I get $1,000,000. In that scenario, I might vote for Bob even though I prefer Alice, and the election result will no longer reflect my preference between Bob and Alice, as was intended. If enough people are successfully bribed this way, the election will be a sham.

vulnerability.p1: In order to manipulate the outcomes for a particular voter, the manipulator needs to know that voter's eventual choices: If Charlie offers to pay me $1,000,000 to vote for Bob, he needs to know that I'll actually vote for Bob before paying me. Otherwise, I can vote for Alice, tell Charlie I voted for Bob to get the $1,000,000, and the bribe has failed.
vulnerability.p2: In traditional elections, votes are secret, making it difficult to manipulate voters. But there aren't any secrets on public blockchains like Ethereum! In most existing voting systems on Ethereum, votes are public, which means manipulation is a serious threat.

why.p1: Ethereum is a core part of clr.fund and other quadratic funding solutions like Gitcoin Grants, because:
why.li1: Ethereum has a great combination of low infrastructure costs and high security (i.e. hard to hack) compared to other electronic voting solutions
why.li2: Ethereum offers seamless interoperability with a large and growing ecosystem of communities and tools that both enhance and benefit from quadratic funding, such as DAOs and identity systems like BrightID
why.li3: clr.fund was built by and for the Ethereum community
why.p2: While moving away from the public-ness of Ethereum isn't an attractive option, building Ethereum-based tools to resist vote manipulation is, which brings us to MACI.

helps.p1: Bribery only works if the briber can confirm that the person they're paying actually goes through with the conditions of the bribe. This is where MACI comes in. With MACI, it's impossible to prove how you voted, so bribers will never know if you did what they paid you to do.
helps.p2: MACI is a set of Ethereum smart contracts and supplementary scripts that effectively transforms public voting systems into private ones, in which 1) participation in a vote and correct vote tabulation are publicly verifiable, but 2) specific voting information is not public, making vote manipulation much more difficult.

how.p1: When you contribute to a project on clr.fund you register an identity with the round coordinator. But at any time before the end of the round, you can invalidate your identity by secretly changing the public key associated with your identity before casting the vote. You can then use a different key pair to sign the vote (which renders the vote invalid, but it's impossible to see if the vote is invalid).
how.p2: MACI does all this using zero-knowledge proofs. These mathematically prove the authenticity of votes without providing any of the details. So bribers can‚Äôt tell what actions the people they bribed took.
how.p4: Whitelisted voters named Alice, Bob, and Charlie register to vote by sending their public key to a smart contract. Additionally, there is a central coordinator Dave, whose public key is known to all.
how.p5: When Alice casts her vote, she signs her vote with her private key, encrypts her signature with Dave's public key, and submits the result to the smart contract.
how.p6: Each voter may change her keypair at any time. To do this, she creates and signs a key-change command, encrypts it, and sends it to the smart contract. This makes it impossible for a briber to ever be sure that their bribe has any effect on the bribee's vote.
how.p7: If Bob, for instance, bribes Alice to vote a certain way, she can simply use the first public key she had registered ‚Å†‚Äî which is now void ‚Å†‚Äî to cast a vote. Since said vote is encrypted, as was the key-changing message which Alice had previously sent to Dave, Bob has no way to tell if Alice had indeed voted the way he wanted her to.
how.p8: Even if Alice reveals the cleartext of her vote to Bob, she just needs to not show him the updated key command that she previously used to invalidate that key. In short, as long as she had submitted a single encrypted command before her vote, there is no way to tell if said vote is valid or not.
how.link: Read more on the technical details of MACI here.

constraints.p: This is cutting-edge technology and comes with a few constraints right now.
constraints.li1: There are limits on the number of projects, contributors, and contributions. This means you may miss out if a round hits capacity but know that it's for the integrity of the round.
constraints.li2: You can only contribute once per round. Once you have contributed, you can add/remove projects and reallocate your funds but you can't increase your total contribution amount.

more.l1: Vitalik Buterin on Minimal anti-collusion infrastructure

heading.p1: The first thing to understand about 'public goods' is that fundamentally, they are fully non-excludable and non-subtractable goods ‚Äî a public good can be from the intangibles (i.e. knowledge) to the tangible social public goods (i.e. street lighting).
heading.p2: In economics, public goods are goods that are both:
heading.li1: Non-excludable ‚Äî no one (who is a member of the "public") can be prevented from using the good, for any reason.
heading.li2: Non-rivalrous ‚Äî one person using the good does not reduce anyone else's ability to use it.
heading.p3: Clean air, national security (for a given country), and free, open-source software (FOSS) are all examples of public goods, with FOSS being the most important for clr.fund.
heading.p4_t2: for a more specific description and context.

why.h2: Why create new funding mechanisms for public goods?
why.p1: Public goods are often underfunded because of something called the free rider problem: since public goods are always free and accessible for members of the public, people have little reason to contribute to their creation and maintenance. Instead, they can choose to be "free riders": using the public good but depending on others to build and maintain it.
why.p2: The free rider problem is quite present in open-source software, which is chronically underfunded despite being a core component of nearly all popular software products today.
why.p3: Clr.fund is an attempt to address the free rider problem for the Ethereum community, with the hope that this infrastructure may be useful for other publics in the future. By design, the funding rounds on clr.fund seek to involve members of the public from inception, and are allocating both decision making power and the exponential power to increase funding via the

heading.p1: Clr.fund is an implementation of quadratic funding, also called CLR (Capital-constrained Liberal Radicalism). Quadratic funding is made up of:
heading.li1: a pool of funds to be distributed
heading.li2: a voting system for distributing those funds
heading.p2: Two common voting systems you may have used are 1-person-1-vote and 1-dollar-1-vote. Quadratic funding is a best-of-both-worlds solution where users vote with the
heading.more: of the money they spend ‚Äî read on to learn more.

problems.p1: The common fund-distribution systems of today all have pluses and minuses:
problems.p2: Markets can be thought of as fund-distributors: sellers are the fund recipients, and buyers are the voters deciding what will be funded. In this case, the "voting system" is 1-dollar-1-vote: each buyer has exactly as much potential influence over where funds go as they have money to spend. This is also the case for traditional crowdfunding platforms like Kickstarter.
problems.p3: An advantage of this system is that each voter's influence is directly proportional to their need (at least, if we ignore wealth inequality). The more Alice needs pizza, the more pizza she'll buy, and the more funding will go to pizzerias.
problems.p4: The disadvantage is that rich voters have an outsize influence on what gets funded. Alice may need pizza exactly as much as Bob needs movie tickets, but if Bob is twice as wealthy as Alice, he has twice as many "votes" to spend on going to the movies.

private.p1: Privately-owned grant-giving institutions, like non-profit foundations, are quite common, but they don't have voting systems. Instead, grants committees and the like solicit grant proposals and then choose which applicants will receive funding internally.
private.p2: An advantage of non-profits is that their non-profit status binds them to **act in the interest of some public mission**, rather than seeking profit above all.
private.p3: On the other hand, the small, private interests that control these organizations lack the tools and incentives to effectively serve large publics.

democratic.p1: Government grants are another common fund-distribution mechanism, and in democracies, these are usually controlled by voting citizens using 1-person-1-vote policies (with elected representatives and other middlemen in between).
democratic.p2: On the good side, these systems are much less oligarchical than markets‚Äîif we ignore the ability to convert money into influence via the media, among other complications.
democratic.p3: In exchange for less oligarchy, though, influence also poorly reflects need in 1-person-1-vote systems. A half-time Florida resident has the same voting power in Florida elections as a full-time resident, as long as both qualify to vote, even though the full-time resident may have twice as much riding on the result.

balance.p1: Quadratic funding is a compromise between 1-dollar-1-vote and 1-person-1-vote. Participants vote on how to distribute pooled funds by making individual donations, but each person's influence, rather than being the amount of money they spend, is the square root of that amount.
balance.p2: Compared to 1-dollar-1-vote in the market, quadratic funding makes it exponentially easier for the influence of many poorer people to outweigh that of a single rich person:
balance.li1: 1-dollar-1-vote: 1 person paying $10,000 has the same influence as 100 people paying $100
balance.li2: Quadratic funding: 1 person paying $10,000 has the same influence as 100 people paying $1 or 10 people paying $100
balance.p3: Compared to 1-person-1-vote, quadratic funding lets the person who lives in Florida full-time, and cares twice as much about the vote's outcome than the person who lives in Florida half-time, have more influence:
balance.li3: 1-person-1-vote: the two Florida voters have equal influence
balance.li4: Quadratic funding: the full-time Florida resident, who cares twice as much, pays twice as much, and as a result gets 2^(1/2) times the influence of the half-time resident
balance.p4: (It's important to note that while these example are a good demonstration of the argument for quadratic funding, they do over-simplify these situations, which are as sociological as they are mathematical.)

resources.li2: Liberal Radicalism: A Flexible Design For Philanthropic Matching Funds

heading.p: An overview of how things work as a recipient so you can learn what to expect throughout the duration of a funding round.

funds.p1: You'll need some {currency} on {chain} in order to submit transactions to the clr.fund smart contracts.
funds.link2: Read our explanation on how clr.fund uses layer 2 on Ethereum.

register.p1: In order to participate in a funding round as a project, you'll need to submit an application to join the recipient registry (via an on-chain transaction).
register.p2_t1: MACI, our anti-bribery tech, currently limits the amount of projects allowed per round.
register.p2_t2: . The round only accepts a total of {maxRecipients} projects, so we encourage you to apply early.
register.p3: Note: all application data (except contact email address) will be publicly stored on-chain.
register.li2: Click "See round criteria" and familiarize yourself with the criteria for projects.
register.li3: Once you're familiar with the criteria and you're sure your project meets them, click "Add project." You'll see a series of forms to fill out asking for more information about your project.
register.li4: With the forms finished, you can finish your submission:
register.li5: Connect to the right network via your wallet of choice.
register.li6: Send a transaction (with a deposit of {depositAmount} {depositToken}) to the registry contract.
register.p4: The registry admin will review project submissions and accept/reject projects according to the criteria.
register.p5: In any case, your {depositToken} will be returned once your application has been either accepted or denied. Note that metadata pointing to all your project information (but not contact information) will be stored publicly on-chain.

claim.p: After a clr.fund round is finished, it's simple to claim your project's share of the funding. Return to your project's page: you will see a "claim funds" button if your project received contributions during the round. Submit the claim transaction to receive your funds.

how.p: Looking for a more general overview?
how.link: Check out our "How It Works" page

heading.p1_t1: A "sybil attack" is when one person pretends to be many people in order to subvert a system's rules. The more a system depends on each participant being a single, unique person, the more potentially vulnerable it is to sybil attacks. Social media is somewhat vulnerable: bots creating email spam and fake follows or likes are examples of relatively toothless sybil attacks. Digital voting systems are more vulnerable: if an attacker can create enough fake users to swing a vote, there can be significant and concrete consequences. Since clr.fund uses
heading.p1_t2: , which is essentially a voting system, sybil attacks are a serious threat.
heading.p2: In the physical world, sybil attacks are hard to pull off. It's pretty difficult to pretend to be someone else for long, especially when most governments issue and check photo IDs and ID numbers. On the internet, though, nobody knows you're a dog. People don't want to share their personal information online and government IDs are impractical for borderless web services, so historically, we haven't had strong methods to stop online sybil attacks.

brightID.p1: BrightID is a platform we use to increase our confidence that you're only contributing once. BrightID is one of a new class of digital identity solutions for use cases like clr.fund that require digital sybil resistance.
brightID.p2: BrightID works using a web-of-trust model: users connect their BrightID accounts with people they trust to be unique humans (generally because they know them personally) and form groups. These connections are public, but users' personal data aren't. If you connect your BrightID to an app, the app can analyze your connections and decide whether or not to allow you access based on how likely you are to be a unique person. The graph of BrightID connections can be analyzed with any method, but generally, the more connections an ID has with other trustworthy-looking IDs, the more trustworthy it is.
brightID.p3: To contribute to projects in a clr.fund round, you must connect a verified BrightID with the clr.fund app. This prevents you from creating 1000s of Ethereum accounts and distorting the contributions.
brightID.link: Get verified by following the directions here

how.p1_t2: here's a quick look at what you can expect:
how.li2: Get verified in BrightID so we know you're a human and not a bot
how.li3_t1: Submit a transaction for clr.fund to sponsor you in BrightID
how.li4: Link your wallet to your BrightID profile, so you can't use multiple Ethereum addresses to sway voting
how.li5_t1: Add yourself to the clr.fund user registry. This is a requirement for

heading.p: BrightID verification helps prove that you‚Äôre a unique human. To get verified, you need enough people to confirm they've met you and you're a real person.

fastest.content: BrightID run verification parties regularly. Join the call, meet other new users, and they'll verify you‚Äôre a human and not a bot. Quick and painless, even for you introverts out there.

brightIDSponsor.p: You need a sponsorship token to become BrightID verified. This helps support BrightID as a decentralized platform. You‚Äôll only ever need to do this once and it covers you for any other app that works with BrightID. Check the BrightID mobile app to see if you're sponsored. If you're not, click the button below to submit a sponsorship request.

brightIDSponsored.subtitle: You‚Äôre almost ready to contribute to your favorite projects! If you're verified for BrightID, link your wallet to your BrightID profile and start contributing.

step0.p1: Describe your project in a sentence. Max characters: 140
step0.error2: This tagline is too long. Be brief for potential contributors
step0.input3: ex: CLR.fund is a quadratic funding protocol that aims to make it as easy as possible to set up, manage, and participate in quadratic funding rounds...
step0.error4: Your project needs a description. What are you raising money for?
step0.error5: You need to choose a category
step0.p5: Explain the problems you're trying to solve. Markdown supported.
step0.input8: ex: there is no way to spin up a quadratic funding round. Right now, you have to collaborate with GitCoin Grants which isn‚Äôt a scalable or sustainable model.
step0.error6: Explain the problem your project solves

step1.p1: The destination address for donations, which you'll use to claim funds. This doesn't have to be the same address as the one you use to send your application transaction.
step1.error1: Enter a valid ENS or Ethereum 0x address
step1.label2: How will you spend your funding?
step1.p2: Potential contributors might convert based on your specific funding plans. Markdown supported.
step1.error2: Let potential contributors know what plans you have for their donations.

step2.p1: Tell us about the folks behind your project.
step2.description1: For important updates about your project and the funding round.
step2.notice1: We won't display this publicly or add it to the on-chain registry.
step2.error1: This doesn't look like an email.
step2.p3: If different to project description. Markdown supported.
step2.input3: ex: CLR.fund is a quadratic funding protocol that aims to make it as easy as possible to set up, manage, and participate in quadratic funding rounds...

step3.p1: Give contributors some links to check out to learn more about your project. Provide at least one.
step3.error1: This doesn't look like a valid URL
step3.error2: This doesn't look like a valid URL
step3.error3: This doesn't look like a valid URL
step3.error4: This doesn't look like a valid URL
step3.error5: This doesn't look like a valid URL

step4.p1: We'll upload your images to IPFS, a decentralized storage platform.
step4.input1: Recommended aspect ratio: 16x9 ‚Ä¢ Max file size: 512kB ‚Ä¢ JPG, PNG, or GIF
step4.input2: Recommended aspect ratio: 1x1 (square) ‚Ä¢ Max file size: 512kB ‚Ä¢ JPG, PNG, or GIF

step5.warning: This information will be stored in a smart contract and cannot be edited, so please review carefully.
step5.notice1: This information won't be added to the smart contract.

step6.p1: This is a blockchain transaction that will add your project information to the funding round.

joinLanding.or_follow_us_on_twitter: . Or follow us on Twitter for updates about future rounds:
joinLanding.need_info_about_your_project: We‚Äôll need some information about your project and a
joinLanding.cap_on_projects: The round only accepts a total of {maxRecipients} projects, so apply now while there‚Äôs still room!

closed.h1: Sorry, it's too late to join
closed.subtitle1: The round is closed for new projects. It's now too late to get on board.

full.subtitle1: The tech we use to protect you from bribery and collusion, MACI, limits the number of projects right now. Unfortunately we've hit the cap and there's no more room on board.

open.div5: MACI, our anti-bribery tech, currently limits the amount of projects allowed per round.
open.p1: You will get your deposit back if you don‚Äôt make it into the round this time.

hero.title: Send your favorite projects to the moon!
hero.subtitle: Every project you contribute to gets a portion of extra funding.

callout.title: Join the funding round
callout.paragraph: Add your project to the next funding round. If you're working on anything related to public goods, you can join in.

how.title: Every donation is amplified by the matching pool.
how.paragraph: This fundraiser rewards projects with the most unique demand, not just those with the wealthiest backers.
how.subtitle: How it works
how.list-1: {operator} and other donors send funds to the matching pool smart contract.
how.list-2: The round begins and you can donate to your favorite projects.
how.list-3: Once the round finishes, the smart contract distributes the matching pool funds to projects weighted primarily by number of contributions,

req.title: What you'll need
req.chain: {chain} for fast and cheap transaction fees
req.bright: BrightID for private, decentralized identity verification

about.title: About
about.paragraph-1: Using quadratic funding, your contribution counts as a vote. Projects with the most contributions at the end of the round get the highest amount from the matching pool. That means even a small donation can have a massive impact.
about.paragraph-2: Using MACI, a zero-knowledge technology, it's impossible to prove how you contributed. This drives bribers insane because they have no idea whether you actually did what they bribed you to do!
about.paragraph-3: clr.fund is a protocol for efficiently allocating funds to public goods that benefit the Ethereum Network according to the prefences of the Ethereum Community.

project.p: You have contributed to this project!

projectAdded.div1: You‚Äôre almost on board this funding round.
projectAdded.li1: Your project just needs to go through some final checks to ensure it meets round criteria. You can
projectAdded.link1: learn more about the registration process here.
projectAdded.li2: Once that's complete, your project page will go live.
projectAdded.li3: If your project fails any checks, we'll let you know by email and return your deposit.

projectList.div1: üò¢ No projects match your search. Try using the filter to narrow down what you're looking for.

transactionSuccess.p3: Your choices have been updated! You can update your choices again any time in the next
transactionSuccess.p4_t1: Thanks for contributing to the Ethereum ecosystem. If you change your mind, you have

verified.div1: You‚Äôre on board this funding round! And fully verified for BrightID for this funding round.
verified.p1: You can now start contributing to your favorite projects.

verify.subtitle: Step {currentStep} of {steps}
verify.p2: You need to connect your BrightID account with your wallet address.
verify.p3: Once this app is linked in your BrightID app, we'll automatically transition you to the next step. It may take a minute for us to verify the connection - please wait.
verify.p4: Scan this QR code with your BrightID app
verify.p5: Follow this link to connect your wallet to your BrightID app
verify.p6: This link might look scary but it just makes a connection between your connected wallet address, our app, and BrightID. Make sure your address looks correct.
verify.p7: To protect the round from bribery and fraud, you need to add your wallet address to a smart contract registry. Once you‚Äôre done, you can join the funding round!

verifyLanding.h1: Prove you‚Äôre only using one account
verifyLanding.subtitle: We use BrightID to stop bots and cheaters, and make our funding more democratic.
verifyLanding.tooltip: If you've previously donated to a CLR round, use the same wallet to bypass some BrightID steps
verifyLanding.li4: An Ethereum wallet, with enough gas for two transactions
verifyLanding.li5: Access to Zoom or Google Meet
verifyLanding.div1: There's not yet an open funding round. Please check back later.
verifyLanding.div2: The current round is no longer accepting new contributions. Please try again next round.
verifyLanding.div3: Contributions closed early ‚Äì you can no longer donate! Due to the community's generosity and some technical constraints we had to close the round earlier than expected. If you already contributed, you still have time to reallocate if you need to. If you didn't get a chance to contribute, you can still help by donating to the matching pool

brightIdWidget.tooltip1_1: You're a verified human on BrightID!
brightIdWidget.tooltip1_2: Your BrightID profile still needs to be verified.

callToActionCard.p1: You still have time to reallocate your contributions.
callToActionCard.p2: You can no longer make any contributions this round.
callToActionCard.p3: You‚Äôll need to set up a few things before you contribute. You can do this any time before or during the funding round.

cart.div1: You‚Äôve already contributed this round. You can edit your choices and add new projects, but your cart total must always equal your original contribution amount.
cart.div2: Almost done! You must submit one more transaction to complete your contribution.
cart.div3: This round is over. Here‚Äôs how you contributed. Thanks!
cart.div4: Sorry, the deadline for donating has passed.
cart.div5: Choose some projects that you want to contribute to...
cart.div9: Remaining funds go to matching pool
cart.div12: Funds you don't contribute to projects ({total} {tokenSymbol}) will be sent to the matching pool at the end of the round. Your cart must add up to your original {contribution} {tokenSymbol} donation.
cart.link4: Verify with BrightID while you wait

contributionModal.contribution_final: contribution total is final. You won't be able to increase this amount. Make sure this is the maximum you might want to spend on contributions.
contributionModal.permission: This gives this app permission to withdraw {renderTotal} {nativeTokenSymbol} from your wallet for your contribution.
contributionModal.send_tx: This transaction sends out your {renderTotal} {nativeTokenSymbol} contribution to your chosen projects.
contributionModal.how_much: This transaction lets the matching pool know how much {nativeTokenSymbol} to send to your favorite projects based on your contributions.

criterialModal.p2: The registry admin will remove any projects that don't meet the round criteria. So read carefully! In later rounds we're hoping that this review process can be done by the community.
criterialModal.p3: Learn more about the project application process in our

fundsNeededWarning.p1: ‚ö†Ô∏è You need both some ETH for gas, and {nativeTokenSymbol} to contribute

ipfsImageUpload.p2: Your image is now stored on a decentralized network at the following hash. You don't need to do anything with it but you may want to keep it for future use.

matchingFundsModal.title: Contribute {tokenSymbol} to the matching pool
matchingFundsModal.h3_3: You just topped up the pool by {renderContributionAmount} {tokenSymbol}!
matchingFundsModal.fund_distribution_message: The funds will be distributed to all projects based on the contributions they receive from the community
matchingFundsModal.div2: Thanks for helping out all our projects.

projectProfile.info1: This is what your contributors will see when they visit your project page.
projectProfile.p1: You have contributed to this project!

recipientSubmissionWidget.div1: Waiting for transaction to be mined...
recipientSubmissionWidget.div2: Check your wallet for a prompt...
recipientSubmissionWidget.div3_t2: Check your wallet or {blockExplorerLabel} for more info.
recipientSubmissionWidget.tooltip1: Estimate ‚Äì this total may be slightly different in your wallet.
recipientSubmissionWidget.div5_t2: Top up or connect a different wallet.

roundInfo.p2: It's now too late to contribute or reallocate your donations! Due to the community's generosity and some technical constraints we had to close the round earlier than expected. You can still help by donating to the matching pool.
roundInfo.tooltip1: During this phase, you can contribute to your favorite projects.
roundInfo.tooltip2: During this phase, you can add/remove projects and change your contribution amounts. You can't make a contribution or increase your overall total.
roundInfo.tooltip3: If you've contributed, you can add/remove projects and change your contribution amounts. Please connect your wallet.
roundInfo.tooltip4: This round has closed for new contributions.
roundInfo.tooltip5: Our smart contracts are busy figuring out final contribution amounts.
roundInfo.tooltip6: If you're a project owner you can now claim your funds!
roundInfo.tooltip7: This total includes the funds in the matching pool and all contributions from the community.
roundInfo.tooltip8: These are the funds that will be distributed to all the projects based on the contributions they receive from the community.
roundInfo.div21: We haven't yet scheduled a funding round. Stay tuned!

roundStatusBanner.span4: Time left to add a project:
roundStatusBanner.span6_t2: left to contribute to your favorite projects
roundStatusBanner.span7_t1: Funding is closed! If you contributed, you have
roundStatusBanner.span8: üéâ Funding is closed! Our smart contracts are busy tallying contributions...
roundStatusBanner.span9: Funding is closed! Contributions are ready to claim. Head to your project page to claim your funds.

transactions.div1: Please approve transaction in your wallet
transactions.small: If you have been waiting a while, consider refreshing your browser and reconnecting your wallet.

withdrawalModal.div1: You have successfully withdrawn your contribution.

free_open_source.description: Your project must be free to use and any code associated with your project should be available to anyone under an open source license.

no_clones.description: If you've forked code, you must provide additional, unique value to the ecosystem.

project_ownership.description: The project you submit must be yours or you must have permission from the project owner.

no_scams.description: Obviously, your project must not put anyone's funds or information at risk.

error.reached_contribution_limit: The limit on the number of contributions has been reached
error.need_to_setup_brightid: To contribute, you need to set up BrightID.
error.exceeded_max_cart_size: Your cart can't include over {maxCartSize} projects.
error.round_cancelled: Sorry, we've had to cancel this funding round.
error.cart_changes_exceed_cap: Cart changes will exceed contribution capacity of this round
error.contributions_over: Contributions are over for this funding round.
error.reached_contributor_limit: The limit on the number of contributors has been reached
error.must_be_gt_zero: Your total must be more than 0 {nativeTokenSymbol}
error.not_enough_funds: Not enough funds. Your balance is {balance} {nativeTokenSymbol}.
error.too_generous: Your contribution is too generous. The max contribution is {maxAmount} {nativeTokenSymbol}.
error.need_gas_payment: You need some ETH to pay for gas
error.contributor_key_missing: Contributor key is not found. Refresh and try again and/or make sure you're using the same browser/machine as the one you contributed with.
error.more_than_original_contribution: Your new total can't be more than your original {total} {tokenSymbol} contribution
